critique: This document is an executive order focused on reorganizing government agencies related to merchant marine activities. It aims to consolidate and coordinate these agencies within the Department of Commerce to reduce expenditures and increase efficiency, as per the policy declared by Congress in sections 401 and 403 of Title IV of Part II of the act approved June 30, 1932. The order transfers various agencies and their functions, personnel, and resources to the Department of Commerce. It also establishes the position of Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Merchant Marine to oversee these activities. The order emphasizes efficiency and consolidation, with no clear ideological tilt. It doesn't directly address immigration, civil liberties, or social inclusion. The focus is on internal government organization and economic efficiency through consolidation, not deregulation or intervention in the broader economy. The order centralizes authority within the Department of Commerce, potentially increasing federal control over merchant marine activities. The order does grant the Secretary of Commerce power to consolidate, eliminate, or redistribute bureaus, agencies, offices, or activities and/or their functions, in the Department of Commerce, which could be seen as an expansion of executive power, but it is limited to internal reorganization and requires Presidential approval.
